results.title: From the ashes of war
results.creator_credit: Michael McKennirey, Nico Crama, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film uses stock shots, photographs, and rare archival film footage to document the liberation of Amsterdam by Canadian troops in May, 1945, and the events preceding it. Some of the worst battles, such as the Battle of the Scheldt and the crossing of the Leopold Canal, are shown. The film is narrated by Alex Colville, internationally known painter, who was an official war artist at the time. The film captures the horror of a people at war and testifies to the strong friendship that developed between Holland and Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael McKennirey, Nico Crama, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: December 25th 1914: a letter from the Western Front by Captain Sir Edward Hulse
results.brief_description: An animated interpretation of Christmas Day in the trenches in 1914 when both sides declared a truce until 4.30 pm. They shared food and songs and played soccer together and repeated the truce again on December 26th. The film raises the issue of killing and war and how the soldiers did not want to kill each other, but that they were acting under orders of their respective Armies. Based on an extract from the diary of Captain Hulse who was later killed in action on March 25th 1915. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Memory of Christmas: from 'Act One' by Moss Hart
results.brief_description: A series of dramatic photographs illustrates playwright Moss Hart’s grievously impoverished childhood. The text, adapted from Hart’s autobiography “Act one” describes two Christmases a generation apart illustrating the gap that existed between himself and his father and how that gap was finally bridged.

results.title: Brazil: the children of the miracle
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, David Elstein and Thames Television
results.brief_description: Looks at the price Brazil is paying for its attempt to turn itself into one of the world’s great powers, by focusing on the city of Sao Paulo, where after fifteen yuears of the ‘economic miracle’, more than half the population lives below the poverty line. Families are so poor that 600,000 children have been abandoned. Presented by Jonathan Dimbleby.

results.title: Court of Petty Sessions
results.brief_description: A dramatised production examining a typical case at a Police Court in Perth - in this instance a car theft. The defendant pleads not guilty so a preliminary trial must be conducted. The testimony of the plaintiff and the defendant is presented and the importance if the subpoena is noted when one witness fails to attend.

results.title: Coping with stress
results.brief_description: Outlines the factors that cause body stress; how the body reacts to stress; the kinds of problems that are stress-related; and ways of coping with stress such as exercise, relaxation, meditation and biofeedback. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: How we adapt
results.creator_credit: William Banting, CTV Television Network and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Notes the increasing amount of stress and stress-related illness in people’s lives. Emphasises the fact that, like some illnesses, stress may also be psychosomatic and controllable by the adoption of stress management techniques. Suitable for tertiary level.

results.title: A Place of dreams: National Air and Space Museum
results.creator_credit: Peter S Vogt and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: An examination of the Smithsonian Institute, home of America’s early planes. Shows through the use of early film and still photographs, the Wright Brothers’ early failures and successes; looks at the restoration of old planes at the museum; and presents a history of the development of flight in the United States. Presented by Cliff Robertson. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Why me?
results.creator_credit: Derek Lamb, Janet Perlman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Everyone ponders how he or she will face the knowledge of certain and imminent death. This animated film shows the reactions of one individual whose doctor has just told him that he has only a short time to live. In a terse and sometimes humorous dialogue with his doctor, Nesbitt Spoon runs the gamut of emotions commonly experienced by people trying to deal with this devastating situation.
